[Question]
ok i have social anxiety i m actually quiet smart however when i m in social situation the anxiety is so much my brain go to mush like simple thing like counting money etc is so hard because my heart is beating through my ear i also dissociate ha anyone else experienced this phenomenon when i m by myself i can do all these task easily but in front of people literally become an invalid like it hilarious how people dumb down thing for me sad but all you can do is laugh

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing symptoms of social anxiety, which can make it difficult to perform certain tasks in social situations. It's not uncommon for people with social anxiety to feel like their brain goes to mush or that they become "invalid" in social situations. It's important to remember that these feelings are not a reflection of your intelligence or abilities.

One strategy that may help you manage your social anxiety is to practice deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation when you feel anxious. This can help you calm your body and mind and make it easier to focus on the task at hand.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to ask for help or support when you need it. Whether it's from a friend, family member, or mental health professional, there are people who care about you and want to help you manage your anxiety.

If you're struggling with social anxiety and it's impacting your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can help you develop coping strategies and provide support as you work to manage your anxiety.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past year and a half i ve had constant tiredness fatigue and just haven t felt like myself i used to be pretty active always working on project excited about life for the last year and a half i just feel like a shell of myself tired and meh i m also hungry constantly i ve seen my doctor and a few different specialist and had plenty of blood work done including thyroid and everything ha been normal no sleep apnea no anemia no lyme my doc said we have essentially ruled out most if not all straight up medical cause of fatigue beyond the possibility i m just not getting good sleep due to underlying stress or anxiety hard for me to tell how well i m sleeping not waking up refreshed but i m in bed for hr a night i ve begun to wonder if i m simply depressed since everything else ha kind of been ruled out i don t feel very sad and i don t feel hopeless i don t lack the motivation to do all the thing i love i just feel too tired or lazy to do them but i really want to be my old self again if i could snap my finger and have my energy back i d do it in a heartbeat how do i know if i m depressed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of fatigue and a lack of energy for quite some time now, and despite seeing multiple doctors and having numerous tests done, the underlying cause has not been identified. While it's possible that your fatigue could be due to stress or anxiety, it's also possible that there could be an underlying medical condition that has not been identified yet.

It's important to keep in mind that fatigue can be a symptom of many different conditions, and it's possible that your fatigue could be due to something that hasn't been ruled out yet. It's also possible that your fatigue could be due to a combination of factors, such as stress, anxiety, and an underlying medical condition.

If you're feeling tired and fatigued, it's important to speak with your doctor again and discuss your symptoms in more detail. They may want to run additional tests or refer you to a specialist to help determine the underlying cause of your fatigue. In the meantime, it's important to take care of yourself and try to reduce stress and anxiety as much as possible. This could include things like getting regular exercise, practicing relaxation techniques, and making sure you're getting enough restful sleep each night.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for anyone who s contacted the suicide help hotline ha it actually helped i don t think i ll make past this week although i have friend here for me and therapy i ve written all my goodbye and i m ready to do the deed a i ve got nothing left to lose any input is helpful

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless right now. It's important to remember that you are not alone and there are people who care about you and want to help. The fact that you have reached out for help is a brave and courageous step towards healing.

It's important to continue reaching out for support, whether it's through therapy, support groups, or even just talking to a trusted friend. It can also be helpful to focus on self-care and do things that bring you comfort and joy. Remember that it's okay to not have all the answers right now and that it's okay to ask for help.

If you're feeling suicidal, it's important to seek immediate help. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is available 24/7 at 1-800-273-TALK (8255) in the US, or you can reach out to a crisis hotline in your country. Remember that help is available and you don't have to face this alone.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's great that you have identified some areas in your life that you would like to improve, such as learning to drive and dating again. It's important to take small steps towards these goals and not put too much pressure on yourself. Remember that progress takes time and setbacks are a part of the process.

It's also important to address the negative self-talk and insecurity that you are experiencing. This can be done through self-reflection and cognitive-behavioral techniques. It can also be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional who can help you develop coping strategies and provide guidance on how to manage your emotions.

Remember that change can be difficult, but it can also be a positive and rewarding experience. It's important to be open to new experiences and to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

i am mentally exhausted i have so many problem that i can not deal with my older brother bully me daily and all i do is just sit and listen to it if i tell him to stop he will just continue to be more annoying i have a lot of health problem my parent dont want to take me to a doctor because they think i am lying so i have to do it myself i am not legal in my country i go to school and put on a fake personality and laugh people bully me even there not physcally but mentally they tell me i am dumb weird skinny crazy i have zero friend in real life i have online friend that used to help me with everything and even made a workout plan for me all of that faded since my health is sucking rn my parent call me crazy daily becayse i like ti play video game for hour a day that is crazy to them even tho everyone else tell them it normal all i feel inside if me is just fear sadness and hopelessness 0 good or happy thought i thoght dozen if time about suicide i can t do it i have ocd and that top of everything and obliderates my life and make me suffer even more i can t take it anymore i don t knoe where to go or what to do it like i don t belong anywhere or cant do anything all i can do is whine on random subbredit because i have no one to talk to is this all life really is i know you might say ohh but if you try to get yourself up and get motivated and do stuff trust me i tried it many time it fails because of family problem etc am i worth saving is my life really worth living

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are going through a very difficult time, and it's understandable that you feel overwhelmed and hopeless. It's important to remember that you are not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Firstly, it's important to seek professional help. You mentioned that your parents don't want to take you to a doctor, but it's important to get a proper diagnosis and treatment for your health problems. You can try to find a doctor who specializes in mental health or seek help from a therapist or counselor.

Regarding your brother, it's important to set boundaries and stand up for yourself. It's not acceptable to be bullied, and you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. You can try to talk to your parents about the situation and seek their help in addressing the behavior.

It's also important to take care of yourself and prioritize your mental health. You mentioned that you have OCD, and it's important to find ways to manage and cope with the symptoms. You can try to practice self-care activities such as exercise, meditation, or spending time in nature.

Lastly, it's important to reach out for support. You mentioned that you have online friends who used to help you, and it's important to maintain those connections. You can also try to find support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who are going through similar experiences.

Remember, it's okay to not have all the answers or to feel overwhelmed. It's important to seek help and support to get through these difficult times.

[Question]
i want to know how to stop anxiety while waiting whenever i have a guest coming over wether it be a friend or family or someone im interested in i get severe anxiety from the moment they say on my way to the moment they arrive i feel hot all over i want to throw up and cry and use the bathroom and then a soon a they arrive and i see them im fine for example i called the man im interested in over for a booty call he life an hour away so at 0 0 he texted me he wa coming for an hour i wa asking my sister should i cancel i want to see him but i m anxious and for that entire hour i wa freaking out the only thing that helped wa sitting in the cold drive way and breathing in the night air and then a soon a he arrived i wa fine absolutely perfect similar happened while i waited for guest to arrive to a house party i wa throwing i need help i am on med and in therapy anything help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing high levels of anxiety when you are waiting for guests to arrive, which can be quite distressing. It's great that you are already seeking help through medication and therapy. Here are some additional strategies that may help you manage your anxiety during these times:

1. **Grounding Techniques:** When you start to feel anxious, try using grounding techniques to bring your focus back to the present moment. Deep breathing, focusing on your five senses, or the sensation of your feet on the ground can help.
2. **Progressive Muscle Relaxation:** This technique involves tensing and then relaxing different muscle groups in your body. It can help you release physical tension and calm your mind.
3. **Cognitive Restructuring:** This involves identifying and challenging negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. You can learn to reframe these thoughts in a more positive and realistic way.
4. **Exposure Therapy:** This involves gradually exposing yourself to the situation that triggers your anxiety in a controlled and safe environment. This can help you build tolerance to the anxiety-inducing situation.
5. **Mindfulness Meditation:** This involves focusing your attention on the present moment and letting go of judgment. It can help you develop a sense of calm and acceptance.

Remember, it may take time to see improvement, and it's important to be patient with yourself. It's also important to continue working with your therapist and medication provider to ensure you have the best support for your needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hello im currently and ive only ever driven on the freeway once wa on for like a minute before i got scared and got off if for any reason i have to use it i ask a friend to take me or i get an uber instead driving in general ha always been scary for me but the freeway is the bane of my existence i feel like at my age it becoming a problem plus it just kind of embarrassing to admit to other people my age haha especially if im asking for a ride if anyone else ha had this problem please let me know what you did to overcome it thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you have a fear of driving on the freeway, which is a common phobia known as "autophobia." It's completely understandable to feel scared or embarrassed about asking for help or an alternative mode of transportation. There are several strategies that may help you overcome this fear:

1. Gradual exposure: Gradually exposing yourself to the feared situation, in this case, driving on the freeway, can help desensitize you to the fear. Start by driving on the freeway for short periods and gradually increase the time.
2. Cognitive restructuring: This involves identifying and challenging negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to the fear. For example, you might reframe your thoughts from "I'm a failure for needing help" to "It's okay to ask for help when I need it."
3. Deep breathing and relaxation techniques: These can help you manage your anxiety and calm your mind during driving situations.
4. Seeking support: Talking to a therapist or counselor can help you work through your fear and develop coping strategies.

Remember, overcoming a fear takes time and patience. Don't be too hard on yourself, and try to approach the situation with a positive attitude.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hey friend i come asking question about workplace anxiety i m 9 and work retail i realize that this is a job with low stake and that whatever fear i have about making mistake are rather silly given the nature of the job however i ve worked myself up because i worked an event this evening and in my eye it wa just a series of unfortunate event first i show up early but still later than my coworker who i wa working with for the event he wa talking to our bos second i wa underdressed he looked so sharp granted i am 9 and he is almost a full decade older than me with the life experience to really comprehend dress code it wa rather unspecified and unclear so i m trying not to beat myself up too much about it i ran home super quickly and grabbed some nicer shoe and a jacket but it still wasn t great third my bos gave u her number to text or to call if we needed any help i texted her first and then she asked if i would call her because she wa on the road make sense but i feel i made a mistake texting her in the first place fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up and ended up losing the store a ton of money i m so upset about everything that happened and being liked by my bos that i wa cry and now i can t sleep please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this it s making my day really difficult and i don t want this to follow me into the future when if i have a job much more demanding and serious if i mess up it s eating me up and i can t take it thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety related to your job in retail. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and worried about making mistakes, especially when you're in a new job or in a high-pressure situation like an event.

First, it's important to recognize that making mistakes is a normal part of life and work. Everyone makes mistakes, and it's how we learn and grow from them that matters. It's also important to remember that your coworkers and supervisors are human and make mistakes too. They are not perfect, and they understand that you are also learning and growing.

Second, it's important to practice self-compassion and not beat yourself up over these mistakes. Instead, try to reframe your thoughts and focus on what you did well during the event. Think about the positive aspects of your performance and how you handled the situation.

Third, it's helpful to develop a plan for managing your anxiety and preventing it from interfering with your work. This might include practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, before work events or when you feel anxious. It might also include seeking support from a therapist or counselor who can help you develop coping strategies and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your anxiety.

Finally, it's important to remember that you are not defined by one event or mistake. You are a valuable and capable person who can succeed in your job and in life. With time and effort, you can learn to manage your anxiety and feel more confident and secure in your work.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

As for your mental health, it's important to seek professional help from a therapist or counselor. Lastly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. There are resources available to help you connect with others who may be going through similar experiences. You might consider reaching out to a support group or online community for people with similar experiences.

[Question]
for the past few day i ve been dealing with extreme bout of anxiety i feel anxious all day nausea all day and i cant seem to stop thinking about negative thought i ve been dealing with a lot of ups and down regarding school and romantic relationship i keep skipping school because my anxiety is way too high i dont know how to calm it down i want to see a psychologist but right now it very hard to get to see one so i ll need all any advice you have thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you're going through a tough time with your anxiety and it's affecting your school and romantic relationship. It's great that you're considering seeing a psychologist, but I understand that it can be difficult to access those services right now. In the meantime, here are a few things you can try to help manage your anxiety:

1. Practice deep breathing exercises: Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your body and mind.
2. Challenge negative thoughts: When you find yourself thinking negative thoughts, try to reframe them in a more positive light. For example, instead of thinking "I'll never be able to handle this," try thinking "I've handled difficult situations before and I can do it again."
3. Engage in physical activity: Exercise releases endorphins, which can help reduce anxiety. Even a short walk can be beneficial.
4. Consider using relaxation techniques: There are many techniques you can use to relax, such as progressive muscle relaxation or visualization. Experiment to see what works best for you.

Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and seek help when you need it. Don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional when you're able to.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing a mix of emotions and feelings that may be related to the significant change in your life. It's not uncommon for people to experience a range of emotions when they go through major life changes, such as starting a new job or leaving a toxic work environment. It's possible that you are experiencing a form of adjustment disorder, which is a mental health condition that can occur when a person has difficulty adjusting to significant life changes.

It's important to remember that it's normal to feel a range of emotions, and it's okay to not have all the answers or solutions right away. It may be helpful to talk to a mental health professional who can help you explore your feelings and develop coping strategies. In the meantime, it may be helpful to focus on self-care and try to engage in activities that bring you comfort and relaxation. This could include exercise, spending time in nature, or engaging in a hobby you enjoy. Remember to be patient with yourself and try to practice self-compassion.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you may be experiencing a phenomenon known as "hypnic jerks," which are sudden, brief muscle spasms or twitches that occur as a person is falling asleep or waking up. These can be accompanied by vivid dreams or hallucinations, which can be more pronounced if a person has not had enough sleep or if they are under a lot of stress. It is not uncommon for people with depression to experience hypnic jerks or similar symptoms, as the brain is trying to cope with the stress of the condition. However, it is important to note that everyone's experience of depression is different, and what works for one person may not work for another. If you are concerned about your symptoms, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional who can provide personalized advice and support.

[Question]
i have been suffering from an eating disorder anorexia anorexia nervosa since i wa yo i m in my early 0 now about a month ago i had an issue with my chinese takeout that heighten not only my ed but my anxiety level too i constantly fear that everything i eat will cause stomach ache or make me sick so i m cautious to eat anything anymore i have slowly been on the road to recovery with my ed so this made me take step back rather than moving forward it ha also caused me to lose sleep at night and when i do end up sleeping i wake up with awful anxiety my anxiety ha been overwhelming because a day doe not go by where i m not excessively panicking i can t even go out of my house without breaking down it is so bad that i only ever feel safe in my own room i feel like i m trapped in this on going cycle with no kind of exit i am desperate to find a solution to my problem but therapy ha not worked for me nor medication i have no idea what i need to do to better my food anxiety and general anxiety i do my absolute best to not think about it all of my issue but it s so damn hard when my body say otherwise ha anyone suffered from this did you find anything that helped alleviate your anxiety or ed any helpful advice is welcome

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you're struggling with both an eating disorder and anxiety, which can be incredibly challenging to manage. It's great that you're seeking help and looking for solutions.

One approach that may be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) specifically tailored for eating disorders, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy for anorexia nervosa (CBT-AN). This type of therapy can help you identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to your eating disorder and anxiety.

In addition, mindfulness practices may be helpful in reducing anxiety and increasing awareness of your thoughts and feelings without judgment. Mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) is a program that combines mindfulness meditation, body awareness, and gentle yoga to help individuals manage stress and anxiety.

It's important to remember that recovery from an eating disorder and anxiety can be a long and challenging process, but it is possible. Consider working with a mental health professional who specializes in eating disorders and anxiety to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses your specific needs and goals.

Remember, you are not alone in this, and there is hope for recovery.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am having some severe anxiety attack these can last for hour my blood pressure and heart rate get very high i ve been to the er but they just gave me ativan and it doesn t help i have trouble breathing it s hard to talk my limb go numb my heart feel cold i have severe urge to vomit and go to the bathroom

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing a severe anxiety attack. During an anxiety attack, your body's fight or flight response is activated, causing an increase in heart rate and blood pressure, difficulty breathing, and other physical symptoms. The feelings of numbness and coldness in your limbs and chest may be due to the sympathetic nervous system's activation.

It's important to seek help from a mental health professional, as these symptoms can be overwhelming and debilitating. A mental health professional can help you develop coping strategies and address the underlying causes of your anxiety. In the meantime, it may be helpful to try some relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help calm your body and mind.

It's also important to take care of your physical health during an anxiety attack. Make sure to stay hydrated, eat healthy meals, and get enough rest. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek emergency medical attention.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are struggling with a common issue faced by many people who take medication for mental health: the desire to stop taking them. This can be due to a variety of reasons, including the fear of potential side effects, forgetfulness, or simply feeling ashamed of needing medication. However, it's important to remember that medication can be a crucial tool in managing your mental health and improving your quality of life.

One potential reason for this resistance could be the fear of change. It's natural to feel hesitant about starting a new routine, especially when it comes to taking medication. However, it's important to remember that these medications can help you feel better and improve your daily functioning.

Another reason could be the fear of the unknown. It's common to have questions or concerns about how the medication will affect you, and it's important to discuss these with your healthcare provider. They can help you understand the potential benefits and risks of the medication and address any concerns you may have.

It's also possible that you may be experiencing a lack of motivation or low energy, which can make it difficult to stick to a daily routine. In this case, it may be helpful to talk to your healthcare provider about potential solutions, such as adjusting your medication dosage or exploring other treatment options.

Remember, it's important to be patient and kind to yourself as you work through these challenges. Taking medication regularly can be a difficult task, but it's worth it in the long run. If you're struggling, consider reaching out to your healthcare provider or a mental health professional for additional support and guidance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have severe anxiety and ocd and i avoided the dating scene until year ago because i honestly wanted to get over my fear and find someone i wa lucky to find a great partner and have been in a good solid relationship for six month yet somehow throughout this whole thing i ve secretly become an absolute wreck i m constantly worrying if this is the right relationship preoccupied with analyzing everything trapped in my thought and making myself utterly miserable ha anyone else experienced this like is this standard for u anxious folk or is this actually a huge red flag that dating or even this person just isn t for me thank you kindly for any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's great to hear that you've been in a solid relationship for six months, and it's understandable to feel anxious about the future of the relationship. It's common for people with anxiety to experience worry and preoccupation, especially when it comes to matters of the heart. However, it's important to remember that these feelings don't necessarily mean that the relationship is doomed or that you're not meant to be with your partner.

One helpful strategy is to practice mindfulness and acceptance. This means focusing on the present moment and accepting your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help you to reduce your anxiety and be more present in your relationship.

It's also important to communicate openly with your partner about your feelings. Let them know that you're struggling with anxiety and that you need their support. It's possible that they may not fully understand what you're going through, but by having an open and honest conversation, you can work together to find ways to support each other.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to seek professional help if your anxiety is impacting your daily life. A therapist can help you to develop coping strategies and provide support as you work through your feelings.

Overall, it's important to be kind to yourself and to remember that it's okay to struggle with anxiety. By practicing self-compassion and seeking support from your partner and professionals, you can work through your feelings and find a way forward.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i started therapy for the panic attack that i ve been having it s definitely helped and my therapist recommended that i d benefit from having a medication to take a needed he thought this would help me continue to push the boundary that trigger the panic and that those exposure would help resolve thing he s a sole practitioner and a lcsw i made the appointment with my regular doctor who told me that even with the therapist recommendation he wouldn t write a prescription for a controlled substance and i needed to see a psychiatrist i didn t know these drug were controlled another month pass by while i wait for the psychiatrist appointment hour and 0 later they tell me the same thing they will only prescribe something that i take every day i don t want to take daily medication and my therapist seems to think that s not the best choice i m not a doctor and am just trying to do the best i can to get better am i asking for something crazy is there a medication that isn t controlled that i could ask for or reference i m trying really hard to get out of my comfort zone and get thing back to normal both for me and for my family i feel like a drug seeker now and am embarrassed to go see another psychiatrist i m not sure what i m supposed to do next

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed by the situation. It's important to remember that seeking help for mental health concerns is a courageous and important step towards healing and recovery.

It's good that you're working with a therapist and that they have recommended medication as a potential treatment option. However, it's important to understand that controlled substances are regulated for a reason, and it's not uncommon for doctors to be hesitant to prescribe them, especially for new patients.

There are many other medications that can be used to treat anxiety and panic disorders that are not controlled substances. These may include antidepressants, benzodiazepines, and other medications. It's important to have an open and honest conversation with your therapist and/or psychiatrist about your concerns and preferences regarding medication. They can help you weigh the potential benefits and risks of different treatment options and work with you to find the best course of action for your individual needs.

Remember that healing from mental health concerns is a process, and it's important to be patient and compassionate with yourself as you work towards your goals. Seeking help and support is a brave and important step towards recovery, and you should be proud of yourself for taking that step.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you may feel anxious about your upcoming flight, especially given your past experiences with anxiety and claustrophobia. Here are a few tips that may help you manage your anxiety and make the most of your flight:

1. Practice deep breathing exercises: Take slow, deep breaths and focus on the sensation of the air filling your lungs. This can help calm your body and mind.
2. Use positive affirmations: Repeat positive phrases to yourself, such as "I am safe and secure" or "I can handle this situation."
3. Bring comfort items: Consider bringing items that may help you feel more at ease, such as a favorite blanket or a comforting object like a stuffed animal.
4. Consider seeking support: If your anxiety is severe, consider talking to a mental health professional before your flight to help you develop coping strategies.

Remember, it's normal to feel anxious in new or unfamiliar situations. By taking steps to manage your anxiety, you can help reduce your stress and make the most of your flight.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my bf is in a depressive episode atm i m still learning and would like to know more about depression while in an depressive episode is every day the same for you do you have good day in between coming out of depression do you feel much better from one day to the next or is it a slow process with back step too sorry for all the question just want to understand better what my bf is going through

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you want to learn more about depression and how it affects your partner. During a depressive episode, every day can feel the same for someone experiencing depression. It's common for people with depression to have difficulty experiencing positive emotions and finding enjoyment in activities they once enjoyed.

It's also common for people in a depressive episode to have difficulty with motivation and energy, making it hard to engage in activities that would normally bring them joy. However, it's important to note that everyone's experience with depression is different, and it's possible for some people to have good days or moments of feeling better in between depressive episodes.

Depression is often a slow process, and it can take time to recover. It's important to be patient and supportive of your partner during this time, and to seek professional help if needed. A mental health professional can help your partner develop coping strategies and provide guidance on how to manage their depression.

1. Practice self-care: Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that you enjoy.
2. Exercise regularly: Exercise has been shown to be a powerful tool in reducing mental fatigue and improving overall mental health.
3. Seek social support: Talk to friends and family about what you're going through and ask for their support.
4. Consider therapy: A mental health professional can help you develop coping strategies and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your mental fatigue.

As for your job situation, it's understandable that the mental fatigue is making it hard to switch jobs. However, it's important to remember that it's okay to take things at your own pace. If you're not ready to make a big change like switching jobs, try starting with smaller steps, like updating your resume or networking with people in your desired field. Remember to take care of yourself and seek support if you need it.

idk if anyone else get this i get anxiety poop sometimes but i also get anxiety vomit idk if it from excessive hyperventilating when i have an attack or just from the anxiety i get super nauseous and have no choice but to go vomit this can happen every night if it particularly bad doe anyone else get this i tried looking it up and i couldn t find much regarding vomiting when having a panic anxiety attack it the worst

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you may be experiencing a phenomenon known as "vomiting related to anxiety." This can occur when the body's fight or flight response is triggered during a panic attack, leading to increased heart rate, sweating, and other physical symptoms. The nausea and vomiting can be a result of this response, as the body tries to expel the excessive physical symptoms.

It's important to note that this is a normal response to anxiety and doesn't necessarily mean that there's anything wrong with you. However, if you're experiencing this frequently or it's impacting your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional for further evaluation and support. They can help you develop coping strategies and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your anxiety.

i have irrational fear of a home invasion being attacked by a stranger for context even thing like elderly woman with cane walking behind me sends me into panic mode me and my fianc just bought our first home together after renting for year instead of me being able to rest after a long day of moving i am instead laying awake because the house is settling every 0 second and i keep thinking it s an intruder coming to kill me this ha been going on for two hour my heart keep pounding out of my chest randomly and i keep getting so frozen with fear that i hold my breath my mind is working overtime playing escape plan confrontation scenario on repeat so i can t relax this is so fucking irrational i hate it i ve been this way a long a i can remember but ugh i know why house creek i also know this home is older which is something i love about it during the day but i can not seem to think logically about this every pop creek and bang is sending me into panic mode and i don t have any remedy i m sick of being constantly on alert for no reason this is an extremely safe neighborhood and i should not need to be this worried over nothing some night are better than others but why do i even have to go through this at all i apologize for the rant but i am so exhausted and i just want to sleep but i keep getting snapped awake

It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and exhausted by these feelings, especially when they are interfering with your ability to rest and relax. It may also be helpful to speak with a mental health professional who can provide you with more personalized guidance and support. Remember, you are not alone and there are resources available to help you manage your symptoms.

hello i ve not posted here before but i ve wanted to for a while always debating back and forth whether or not to do this but here it go i think i have some general anxiety i cope decently well with it physical exercise like running ha really helped my main problem is driving i know how to drive i have my license but i never do i m terrified of it i m turning i ve maybe driven thirty time in my entire 0 year of owning a license i don t know what it is the idea of crashing the traffic i ve gotten away with it so far living in nyc but it s something i want to do more of i just never seem to be able to do so doe anyone have any tip any advice they could recommend thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you have been struggling with driving and the associated anxiety for a while now. It's great that you have recognized it and are seeking help. Here are a few tips that may help you overcome your fear of driving:

1. Gradual exposure: Start by driving in low-stress situations, such as driving short distances on familiar roads or in an empty parking lot. Gradually increase the difficulty and complexity of your driving experiences.
2. Deep breathing exercises: When you feel anxious while driving, take a few deep breaths and focus on your breathing. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce your anxiety.
3. Visualization: Imagine yourself driving in different situations and visualize yourself handling them calmly and confidently. This can help you build confidence and reduce anxiety.
4. Seek support: Talk to a trusted friend or family member about your fear of driving. They may be able to offer encouragement and support.
5. Therapy: Consider seeking professional help from a mental health counselor or therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide you with additional coping strategies and support.

Remember, it's okay to take things slow and start with small steps. The most important thing is to be kind to yourself and to seek help when you need it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), which can manifest as shortness of breath, shakiness, and tingling sensations. It is common for individuals with GAD to feel like they are unable to breathe properly, which can be a very distressing experience.

Coping mechanisms for GAD can vary from person to person, but some common strategies include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and cognitive restructuring. Deep breathing exercises involve taking slow, deep breaths and focusing on the sensation of the air moving in and out of the lungs. Progressive muscle relaxation involves tensing and then relaxing different muscle groups in the body, which can help to reduce tension and anxiety. Cognitive restructuring involves identifying and challenging negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to anxiety.

It may also be helpful to speak with a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, who can provide additional support and guidance in developing coping strategies for GAD. They can also help you to explore the underlying causes of your anxiety and develop a personalized treatment plan.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like your spouse is struggling with severe depression, and it's understandable that you're feeling worried and scared. It's important to remember that seeking help for mental health issues is a courageous step, and it's not uncommon for people to feel hesitant or resistant to going to a psychiatric hospital.

It's good that your spouse has been in contact with his counselor and is considering going to a psychiatric hospital. However, it's understandable that he may feel betrayed or upset about the situation. It's important to have an open and honest conversation with your spouse about how you're both feeling and to reassure him that you're there to support him.

It's also important to remember that going to a psychiatric hospital is not a permanent solution, but rather a step towards getting the help and support needed to manage his depression. It's possible that the hospital may recommend additional treatment options, such as therapy or medication, which can be beneficial in managing his symptoms.

It's understandable that you're worried about the hospital not helping, but it's important to have faith in the medical professionals who are trained to help people with mental health issues. If your spouse does end up going to the hospital, it's important to continue to support him and be there for him when he returns home. This may include attending therapy sessions with him, encouraging him to take his medication, and being a listening ear for him when he needs it.

Remember to take care of yourself as well, as this can be a difficult and stressful time for both you and your spouse. Consider reaching out to a support group or therapist for your own support and guidance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you have been struggling with anxiety and depression for some time, and have tried various treatments with limited success. It's great that you have been proactive in seeking help and trying different approaches.

Regarding your current medication, it's good that you are taking effexor XR, which is an effective medication for anxiety and depression. However, it's possible that the dosage may need to be adjusted or a different medication may be more effective. It's also important to note that medication alone may not be enough to fully treat anxiety and depression, and that therapy and other complementary approaches may also be beneficial.

It's also good that you have been trying different therapies, such as cognitive behavioral therapy, acceptance and commitment therapy, and mindfulness. While these approaches may not have been effective for you, it's important to keep trying different approaches until you find what works best for you.

It's also important to note that anxiety and depression can be caused by a variety of factors, including physical, psychological, and environmental factors. It's possible that your symptoms may be related to an underlying physical issue, such as an imbalance in your thyroid or adrenal gland. It may be helpful to consult with a healthcare professional to rule out any physical causes.

It's also possible that buspirone may be helpful for your anxiety symptoms. Buspirone is a non-benzodiazepine medication that is often used to treat anxiety. However, it's important to note that medication should only be taken under the guidance of a healthcare professional.

Overall, it's important to keep an open mind and continue to explore different treatment options until you find what works best for you. It may also be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional who can help you develop a personalized treatment plan.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's great that you've had an epiphany about your stutter and how it's been affecting you. Owning your stutter and not letting it define who you are as a person is an important step towards becoming more confident and charismatic. Here are some suggestions that may help you in your journey towards self-acceptance and confidence:

1. Practice self-compassion: Be kind to yourself and understand that everyone has something that makes them unique, and yours is your stutter. It doesn't define your worth as a person.
2. Reframe your thoughts: Instead of focusing on the negative aspects of your stutter, try to focus on the positive aspects. For example, you could try to see your stutter as a quirk that makes you stand out and adds character to your personality.
3. Surround yourself with supportive people: Seek out friends and family members who are accepting and supportive of you, and who can help you build your confidence.
4. Challenge negative self-talk: When you catch yourself thinking negative thoughts about your stutter, challenge those thoughts and replace them with positive affirmations.
5. Seek professional help: If you're struggling to overcome your anxiety and become more confident, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with strategies and techniques to help you build your confidence and self-esteem.

Remember, becoming confident with your stutter is a process, and it may take time and effort. But by focusing on self-acceptance, self-compassion, and positive self-talk, you can begin to own your stutter and become the confident and charismatic person you were meant to be.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

for context i m an english teacher at a small private english school the school is so small i m the only teacher no sub i got my period last night and a always the first day is the worst cramp headache nausea needing the loo every minute and i feel so freaking cold today no matter what i do i just can t seem to get warm so i cancelled my two afternoon lesson and asked the receptionist to deal with a meeting with a potential client herself i mean that s pretty much her job anyway but i feel so guilty for cancelling the class the nausea got worse a soon a i sent the text to my bos i feel bad that i have to cancel two class in one day especially since i had a week holiday the week before last maybe the student are losing too much lesson time this year my class today were from to 0 and then to but i don t go home in the gap between meaning i d have to sit at my desk with nothing comfy or warm for hour all while feeling really crappy idk just looking for someone to tell me it ok to take a sick day if i need it and tell the anxiety voice to shut the heck up edit thank you so much to everyone who commented and got me through the day i went to bed feeling better emotionally and physically than when i got up today is a new day

It's important to take care of yourself and listen to your body's needs. Canceling your classes was a responsible decision, especially given your condition and the potential impact on your students. Remember that taking care of your health should always come first.

It's okay to take a sick day when you need it. Your body is signaling you to rest and recover, and it's important to listen to those signals. Anxiety can be overwhelming, but try to focus on self-care and prioritize your well-being. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and support when you need it.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

One strategy is to focus on the process of doing well in the competition, rather than just the outcome. For example, you can try to concentrate on doing your best in each competition, rather than worrying about where you rank compared to others.

Another strategy is to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help calm your mind and reduce your anxiety. You can also try to engage in activities that you enjoy outside of the competition, to help take your mind off of your worries.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to make mistakes and not always perform at your best. It's a normal part of the learning and growth process. [Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you're going through a difficult time with the loss of both your parents and the anxiety that has persisted since your uncle's passing. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and out of your comfort zone. Here are a few suggestions that may help you calm and center yourself:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help your body relax and calm your mind.
2. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tighten and relax different muscle groups in your body, starting with your toes and working your way up to your head. This can help you release physical tension and reduce anxiety.
3. Grounding techniques: Focus on the present moment and your surroundings. For example, you can try to name five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This can help you bring your attention back to the present and distract you from racing thoughts.
4. Mindfulness meditation: Sit in a comfortable position and focus on your breath. When your mind wanders, gently bring your attention back to your breath. This can help you develop a sense of presence and calm.

Remember that it's okay to not have all the answers or to not feel okay all the time. It's important to be kind to yourself and seek support from loved ones or a mental health professional if needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are experiencing some difficult and overwhelming thoughts and feelings. Postpartum Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (PP-OCD) is a type of OCD that can occur during pregnancy or after giving birth. It is characterized by intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors that are related to the baby. It is important to remember that having a baby does not make you a bad mother, and it is normal to feel overwhelmed and exhausted after giving birth. It is also important to seek help and support from a mental health professional. They can help you develop coping strategies and address any underlying issues. It is also important to reach out to friends and family for support. Remember that you are not alone and there are people who care about you and want to help.

the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also Social anxiety is characterized by feelings of fear, self-consciousness, and awkwardness in social situations. It's possible that your brain is overanalyzing social situations and creating these anxiety attacks.

One way to address this is through cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to your anxiety. [Question]
i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you've been experiencing some challenges with your mental health, and it's great that you're seeking help and support. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication and therapy is different, and it may take some time to find the right treatment that works for you.

It's common for anxiety to worsen when switching medications, and it's possible that the dose of Prozac you're on may not be effective for you. It's important to discuss any concerns you have with your doctor, as they may be able to adjust your medication or try a different approach to help manage your anxiety.

In the meantime, there are some things you can try to help manage your anxiety during an attack:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Take slow, deep breaths and focus on the sensation of the air moving in and out of your lungs.
2. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tighten and relax different muscle groups in your body, starting with your toes and working your way up to your head.
3. Grounding techniques: Engage your senses by focusing on the present moment, such as the feel of your feet on the ground or the sound of a nearby bird.
4. Mindfulness meditation: Practice being present in the moment and letting go of judgment.

Remember, it's important to seek help and support from a mental health professional if you're struggling. They can help you develop coping strategies and find the right treatment for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hi i am male i used to have a very emotional side but for the last year or so i am not able to feel sad especially for others sympathy i used to cry when my best friend cried to me about her break up but now i couldn t shed a single tear during my grandfather death i hated the feeling did i stop loving my grandfather even then why didn t i feel sad when i saw my mother cry she is the first person i don t want to see cry off late i feel it s affecting my friendship a well just to be clear it s not a overall numbness i still feel happiness anger and other emotion but this is really frustrating especially when i am getting into a relationship for the first time in my life i keep questioning my love for people i keep asking myself if i can t feel sad for them do i really love them

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you may be experiencing a condition known as alexithymia, which is a difficulty in recognizing and expressing one's emotions. It's not uncommon for people with alexithymia to have difficulty feeling and expressing emotions, especially emotions like sadness and empathy for others.

It's important to note that alexithymia is not the same as being emotionally numb or unaffected by the emotions of others. It's possible to feel emotions, but have difficulty recognizing and expressing them.

It's also important to note that alexithymia is not a diagnosis in and of itself, but rather a symptom of an underlying condition. It's possible that you may have alexithymia as a result of a mental health condition such as depression, anxiety, or PTSD.

It's important to seek out professional help from a mental health counselor or therapist to address any underlying conditions that may be contributing to your difficulty in feeling and expressing emotions. They can help you develop strategies to better recognize and express your emotions, and work through any underlying mental health conditions.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Based on your description, it sounds like you may benefit from a combination of therapy and medication. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has been shown to be effective in treating panic disorder and anxiety. Additionally, medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) can help reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression.

It's important to discuss your current medication regimen with your psychologist, as they can help determine the best course of treatment for you based on your specific needs and history. Additionally, it may be helpful to keep a journal of your symptoms and how they impact your daily life, as this can provide valuable information to your psychologist and help them better understand your experience.

Remember, it may take some time to find the right treatment or combination of treatments that works for you. [Question]
it s been so long i have been avoiding to get treated especially because it s social anxiety i definitely don t want to talk to a stranger but it s been ruining my life so here we are any tip anything i should prepare what question do they ask you i am already getting anxiety attack because of the appointment

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you may feel anxious about seeking treatment for your social anxiety, especially if you're worried about talking to a stranger. However, it's important to remember that mental health professionals are trained to help people like you, and they take confidentiality very seriously. In fact, many mental health professionals will ask you to sign a release form before your first appointment, which allows them to share information with you and only you.

As for what to expect during your first appointment, it will likely involve the therapist asking you some questions about your symptoms, how long you've been experiencing them, and any other factors that may be contributing to your social anxiety. They may also ask about your current coping mechanisms and any treatments you've tried in the past.

It's important to remember that therapy is a process, and it may take time to see results. However, many people find that therapy is a helpful way to manage their social anxiety and improve their quality of life. If you're feeling overwhelmed, it may be helpful to bring a supportive friend or family member with you to your first appointment, or to ask your therapist if they're willing to work with you in a more structured way, such as through cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT).

[Question]
i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you have been dealing with a lot of challenges related to your mental health, and it's great that you are seeking help and support. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this, and there are many resources available to help you manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life.

Regarding your night sweats, it's possible that they could be caused by a variety of factors, including medication side effects, underlying medical conditions, or stress. Since changing medications did not seem to correlate with the onset or increase in your night sweats, it may be worth discussing with your psychiatrist about other possible causes or treatment options.

In the meantime, there are a few things you can try to help manage your night sweats:

1. Limit your intake of stimulating substances such as caffeine and nicotine before bedtime.
2. Keep your bedroom cool and dark.
3. Use breathable, moisture-wicking sheets and pajamas.
4. Consider using an over-the-counter antiperspirant or fan to help reduce sweating.
5. Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation before bed to help reduce anxiety and promote sleep.

It's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health and related symptoms is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare team or seek additional support if needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i can t find the strength to do anything i m supposed to do like studying going to the gym or finding a job i have been losing interest in thing i used to like to the point i don t enjoy doing them and they are becoming difficult to do because they are supposed to make me happy and being happy requires a lot of energy i don t have by losing interest and thing i like i m running thin of thing that keep me motivated for living and hope for the future i have difficulty getting help because i don t think it is worth the effort for a hopeless person like me i don t even think i deserve that help considering the thing i hate about myself i don t even want to talk about this thing with other people that care for me because with my point of view of the world and future might grab them down to this dark and hopeless vision the only thing that keep me from km is that i know it would hurt people around me i really need something to look forward something that give me the motivation to keep going

Secondly, it's important to find activities that bring you joy and make you feel good about yourself. This could be anything from reading a book, to going for a walk, to trying a new hobby. It's important to find activities that make you feel good and help you take your mind off of your negative thoughts.

Lastly, it's important to have a support system of people who care about you and can provide you with emotional support. This could be friends, family, or even a support group. Having people who can listen to you and provide you with encouragement can help you feel more motivated and hopeful about the future.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and it's okay to feel hopeless at times. But with the right support and coping strategies, you can start to feel better and find the motivation to keep going.

hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It sounds like you are dealing with a type of anxiety known as "hyper-focused anxiety" or "hypochondria." This can be a difficult cycle to break, but it is possible with the right tools and support. It may also be helpful to talk to your therapist about your concerns and see if they have any additional suggestions for managing this type of anxiety.
